learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate a broad knowledge of the principles that underpin environmental law in Australia.
Reflect on and engage in critical analysis of environmental law issues from a multi-disciplinary perspective.
Communicate to suit different contexts/audiences and in different forms.
Identify issues and explore solutions to theoretical and practical questions arising from the study of environmental laws at the Commonwealth and Queensland levels.

assessments.due_date:
23/03/2026 - 29/05/2026

A sign-on sheet will be distributed in Week Five.
assessments.task_description:
Step 1: Group presentation 30% (15 mins plus 10 mins Q&A)

By Week Four, you will form a small group (4-5 students) that you will complete this task with. These students must be in your seminar. In Week Five, your group will sign on to a week to give the presentation (available weeks are Weeks 7, 8, 9, 11, 12, 13).

Topic choice

Your group will choose a topic in an allocated area of the course:

  • Week Five presentations - protected areas or environmental impact assessment
  • Week Seven presentations - protected areas or environmental impact assessment
  • Week Eight presentations - challenging legal decisions regarding the environment
  • Week Nine presentations - offences and compliance
  • Week Eleven presentations - restoration
  • Week Twelve presentations - environmental markets and corporate regulation
  • Week Thirteen presentations - climate change and biodiversity

Your group must conduct research and present to the class an update on a development/emerging issue in this area. This must be an area that builds upon the course content, and can be an example from Australia or overseas. It must be related to environmental law. You may discuss your topic choice with the course coordinator.

Due date

Presentations will be held in the final hour of your seminar.

Format

All group members must be present for the session. Your group will be presenting to the course coordinator and your fellow students.

You may use a range of media to support your in-person presentation e.g. PowerPoint, poster, infographic, short video element, handouts.

Group input

All group members must contribute to selecting, developing, researching, and presenting the topic. The oral component of the presentation may be given by a single group member or some/all of the members. However, all group members must be prepared to answer questions during the Q&A component. Every group member will receive the same mark, unless a case is made otherwise. Your presentations will be recorded.

Resources to support your group work will be provided on the course BlackBoard and discussed in class.

Step 2: Individual reflection 10% (1-2 pages maximum)

On the day of your presentation (i.e. by midnight), you will submit an INDIVIDUAL reflection on your experiences during this task. This will include reflection on your topic choice, your contribution to the work, and the group work process. Further guidance will be provided in class.

Artificial intelligence use

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The presentation will be in person. The reflection must be submitted electronically in through Cadmus.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
In each seminar students will analyse 2-3 readings using a critical analysis template. Students may choose a reading from one seminar (Weeks 2, 3, 4, 5, 7, 8, 9, 11, 12, NOT week 13) and submit a written critical analysis of it, structured around the template. This analysis is due the week following the seminar on Tuesday at 2pm (e.g. if a student chooses to submit a critical analysis of a reading from Week 3, their critical reflection is due Week 4, Tuesday at 2pm).

The reflection must be no more than 3 pages, 12 point font, with standard margins. Full referencing must be provided.

The purpose of this task is to practice using the critical analysis structure, and receive feedback ahead of the exam.

As there are multiple opportunities for submission, extensions will not be granted.

Artificial intelligence

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You will be using Cadmus to complete this assessment. Cadmus is an online environment for written assessment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
An end-of-semester exam will be held in the central examination period. You will be provided with a reading, and asked to critically analyse it using the critical analysis framework. The exam will be closed book, and completed in-person.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 2 To Week 13(02 Mar - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Seminars

This course will have 3 hour seminars in Weeks 2, 3, 4, 5, 7, 8, 9, 11, 12, 13. There will also be short pre-recorded lectures in some weeks. The seminar topics and descriptions are available from the course Blackboard site.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
